description.narrative: Establishing and Strengthening 9 Village Development Committees,Conducting hazard, vulnerability and capacity assessments at each village, to create 9 Disaster Plans,Conducting 18 disaster simulation drills in the target communities, with early warning and evacuation strategies,Identify and train 50 community leaders to subsequently conduct 150 community discussions related to community issues, including conflict management, gender based violence, social exclusion,Through the trained community leaders, plan and implement 150 community based psychosocial activities including social events, traditional celebrations, actions to build solidarity and include the most vulnerable,Training on livelihood opportunities through disaster resilient livelihood methodologies, including better seed types,Reconstruction of 500 cattle sheds, and distribution of 500 heads livestock,Distribution of multi-purpose micro-finance cash grants for income generating ventures,Training for masons and carpenters on disaster resilient shelter reconstruction techniques,Training of Trainers for community mobilizers on household ownership of reconstructed shelters,Construct latrines conduct training on usage and mainetance in 200 schools,Establishing Water Committees to maintain the 20 water schemes that will be constructed or rehabilitated,Conducting hygiene promotion training through each of the 9 village development committees

While DCA continues to participate in the global ACT appeal, their portion is not yet fully funded. Episcopal Relief & Development support would fill that gap in the ACT appeal but also go beyond the ACT appeal so that DCA can expand their work in livelihood recovery and disaster resilience. Activities though this programme include: repairs to 3,000 households toilets and 5 community water schemes, distribution of shelter grants to 2,000 households, support for a livelihood recovery programme, including skills training for 45 masons and carpenters to build back better, psyshosocial assistance to 4,000 to recover from the impacts of the disaster, mentally, physically and economically. A key emphasis of all activities is to incorporate disaster resilience through better building techniques, better hygiene preparation during disasters, reinforcing water and sanitation infrastructure, and disaster (flood) resilient rice and seed varieties. All activities will target the districts of Gorkha and Dhading, as two of most affected but least accessible districts. The target communities are located in the isolated high hills, and inhabited by ethnic minority groups.
